question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the 1000th digit to the right of the decimal point when $\frac{4}{15}$ is expressed as a decimal?
inference:
To find the 1000th digit to the right of the decimal point when $\frac{4}{15}$ is expressed as a decimal, we perform the long division.
$$
\begin{array}{c|cccccccccc}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{0.} & 2 & 6 & 6 & 6 & 6 & 6 & 6 & \dots \\
\cline{2-10}
15 & 4. & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \dots \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{3} & 0 \\
\cline{2-3}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{1} & 0 \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{9} & 0 \\
\cline{3-4}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 9 & 0 & 0 \\
\cline{4-5}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 9 & 0 & 0 \\
\cline{5-6}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
\end{array}
$$
We see that the decimal representation of $\frac{4}{15}$ is $0.2666\dots$. The repeating part is 6.
The repeating block is 6, and its length is 1.
The remainder is 4, and the division repeats.
The repeating part starts at the 2nd digit after the decimal.
So the 1000th digit is the 999th digit in the repeating part of 6.
The 999th digit in the repeating block is the same as the $999 \pmod 1$ digit in the repeating block, which is 6.
Final Answer: $\boxed{6}$
ground_truth: Using long division, we find that $\frac{4}{15}=0.2\overline{6}$. Therefore, every digit to the right of the decimal point besides the $2$ in the tenths place will be $6$. The 1000th digit to the right of the decimal point is $\boxed{6}$.

The repeating part starts at the 2nd digit after the decimal.
So the 1000th digit is the 999th digit in the repeating part of 6.

inference:
The repeating block is 6, and its length is 1.  The 1000th digit is the 999th digit in the repeating part. Since the length of the repeating block is 1, the 999th digit is the same as the $999 \pmod{1} = 0$th digit in the repeating block, which is 6.

Final Answer: $\boxed{6}$
ground_truth: Using long division, we find that $\frac{4}{15}=0.2\overline{6}$. Therefore, every digit to the right of the decimal point besides the $2$ in the tenths place will be $6$. The 1000th digit to the right of the decimal point is $\boxed{6}$.
